Course_Name: Current Topics in Intelligence Research: Quantitative Approaches to Behavior

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, Next week Friday (July 19) the presentations will take place (in room 2.057). You will have 10 minutes to present your work and we'll have about 5 minutes for questions. Please practice your presentation and make sure that you stick to 10 minutes. The deadline for uploading your pipeline's ethograms is Wednesday the 17th of July. You can upload them using the following link: https://tubcloud.tu-berlin.de/s/ectfBkDJJHS4zqp QAB-ethograms-2024  As mentioned during the tutorial, I added some plotting code on ISIS which you can use to plot tracks in 2D on top of a video (for example, your 3D Kalman-filtered reconstruction of the scene, reprojected into one of the camera views. Feel free to use it, or add stuff, such as an indicator for frame-per-frame interaction detections.  Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all,  The end of the semester is slowly coming to an end, so I want to make sure everyone is aware of the deadlines. There will be two deliverables: the ethograms generated by your pipeline, and the report. Furthermore, you will present your work on the 19th of July. All three are necessary requirements for the course.  Ethograms (deadline 17.07): Please save the ethograms generated by your pipeline for the two experiments in two separate npz files as numpy arrays (you can use the function numpy.savez for this). The (2-dimensional) numpy arrays should have the following shape: [nr of lockbox mechanisms (order: lever, stick, ball, door), nr of frames]. The encoding of interactions is binary (for example, if the mouse is interacting with the ball in frame 10, then the array should contain a 1 for that particular index). Please name the files as follows: [experiment number]_[last names of students].npz. You can upload the files using the following link & password: https://tubcloud.tu-berlin.de/s/ectfBkDJJHS4zqp QAB-ethograms-2024 Presentation (19.07): During the last lecture of the semester, you will present your work. In your presentation I expect you to give a short overview of the methods you applied, the additional behavioral analysis that you performed, future work ideas, and your learnings & struggles during the project. Since some students only audit the course, I do not have an exact overview of who is taking the course for credits. Please fill in the short ‘Presentation schedule’ questionnaire on the ISIS page by this Friday, 05.07, so that I know how many presentations will take place on the 19th. Based on that, I will inform you about the maximum length of your presentations. Report (deadline 16.08): In your report, you should provide a more detailed description of your pipeline. The report should have a standard scientific format, including an introduction, methods section, results, discussion, and references. The report should be about 10 pages long (if you have many figures, it will be a bit longer). Please add your code to the report either as an appendix or share your git repository with me. Please mail me your report by Friday the 16th of August. The ‘labeled-data’ folder for your DLC project is part of the deliverable for the report (see my earlier announcement). Please don’t forget to upload it (as a zip file) using the following link: https://tubcloud.tu-berlin.de/s/7ExLwGZWRTSrJkC TkyhrwIxL&c0hqa   Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, Tomorrow's tutorial will take place in room 5.013. There should be enough power sockets there. Best, Mark

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Pipeline step 1: DLC tracks for your project

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, During last Friday’s tutorial I learned that Google Colab’s free resources are unfortunately very limited. Many groups struggle to train a decent tracker with the available resources. I therefore decided to provide you with tracks so that you can continue with the rest of the project. I understand that some groups might have already spent a lot of time on labeling, debugging, and trying to get the tracker to work, while others might just be starting up with the project. To make sure that everyone went through the process of generating their own training data and thought about the necessary design choices for this step of the pipeline, please upload your ‘labeled-data’ folder from your DLC project to the TUBcloud using the following link & password: https://tubcloud.tu-berlin.de/s/7ExLwGZWRTSrJkC TkyhrwIxL&c0hqa Please upload the data as a zip file and include your last names in the name of the zip file. Feel free to add your ideas and attempts to get the tracker to work to the final report. I will upload the DLC tracks to ISIS by the end of the day. If you managed to train your own tracker, you are welcome to use your own tracks instead. Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all,  This Friday we won't have a lecture or talk. Instead, you will have the chance to ask questions and work on the project.  I will try to find a different room that is more suitable for bringing laptops and working on your project. I will announce the new room if I can find one.  I furthermore made some snippets of code available on ISIS which should help you with detecting interactions with the lockbox (in 3D). The manual annotations that you can use for benchmarking are also uploaded to ISIS.  Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all,  I found a more suitable room for tomorrow's tutorial. We will have the tutorial in room MAR 6.051.  Best, Mark

Discussions.Discussion_Name: This week's talk by Oren Forkosh

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, This Friday Oren Forkosh will give a research talk, who uses machine learning to study personality, behavior, and social learning in mice and other animals (https://www.forkoshlab.com). You can find an abstract and title of the talk on the ISIS page. Best, Mark

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Tomorrow's research talk by Ann Kennedy

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, For tomorrow’s lecture we will have Prof. Ann Kennedy from the Northwestern University to give a research talk (kennedylab.org). She is a theoretical neuroscientist studying the structure of behavior and the neural mechanisms of behavior control. Please find the title and abstract on the ISIS page. See you all there tomorrow! Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, Since the project is quite involved and I have received several questions about various steps of the pipeline, I decided to make some changes in the seminar schedule. The progress presentations on the 28th of June will be replaced by multiple tutorials / hackathons on the project. During these days, you can work on your project and ask me (and other students) questions about the project. I am planning to schedule two of such sessions and I will soon let you knows which Fridays will be used for this. During the last lecture of the semester (19th of July) you will present your project and we will test which pipeline won the ethogram benchmark challenge. In your presentation, you will explain the choices that you made and report on your analyses. Best, Mark

Discussions.Discussion_Name: This week's lecture: research talk by Caleb Weinreb

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, This Friday we will have an exciting talk on methods of behavioral clustering by Caleb Weinreb from the Datta lab (Harvard University), see the abstract below. The speaker will join us through Zoom, and the talk will be broadcasted in our regular lecture room (MAR 2.057). Even though this talk will take place on Zoom, I would kindly like to ask you to attend the lecture at 2.057 in person. I put the preprint of his recent work on ISIS, which you can read as preparation. Best, Mark ///// Abstract: Animals generate a vast array of behaviors by composing together a small set of stereotyped actions. By classifying these action motifs (or “syllables”) and identifying their occurrence in behavioral recordings, researchers can better understand the complex ways that behavior is altered by drugs, genes, neurons, and environmental affordances. Over last few years, keypoint tracking has emerged as a powerful method to measure animal pose over time, and there are now several methods for unsupervised segmentation of animal behavior using keypoints as inputs. In this talk, I will discuss landscape of such methods: their strengths, weaknesses, and core assumptions – with special focus on keypoint-MoSeq, which was developed in our lab. My goal is to provide a conceptual overview of the field, clarifying when these methods are (and are not) useful and how they can best be applied.

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, I uploaded additional information about the projects to the ISIS page. You can now start implementing the first step of your pipeline. If you don’t have a project partner yet, please pair up with someone as soon as possible (you can use the student Q&A to ask around). Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, This week’s lecture will consist of a workshop given by Niels Poulsen, a software engineer at DeepLabCut (www.deeplabcut.org). This workshop will be given in an inverted classroom style, which will consist of an interactive session working with the DeepLabCut software (you will need to bring you laptop; no need to install anything). There is some homework that you will need to do to prepare yourself for the workshop: Introduction to Computer Vision and DeepLabCut, Prof. A. Mathis (EPFL) (Optional) Multianimal pose tracking with DeepLabCut, Prof. A. Mathis (EPFL) Please watch the video(s) before the workshop! Since we will have an interactive session, the workshop will take place in room 2.013 instead of room 2.057. Best, Mark

Discussions.Discussion_Name: Exam registration on Moses now opened

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Dear all, It is now possible to register for the course on Moses. The registration will remain open until the 17th of May. Please register as soon as possible. Students who are not officially registered at the TU and therefore cannot register via Moses will need register by sending an email to me, stating your name, matriculation number and home university (m.boon@tu-berlin.de).  Best, Mark

Messages.Author: Ben Nikolas Baute
Messages.Content: How do you read the provided ethogram? The shape is (2, 4, 24188). In the video of experiment 1 there are about 16600 frames. How does this fit? On Isis the explanation is that there 24188 (nr of frames of the shortest video). Even the longer video has less than 20.000 frames. Is there something different with the frame rate?

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: Hi Ben, thanks for letting me know. The videos for experiment 1 were originally longer (with a length of 13m26s), but I cut them since the trial ends directly after the mouse is eating the reward. The ethograms were still in the old format. I now cut the ethograms to 16650 frames (9m15s) and reuploaded them. You can either use the new ethograms, or compare your pipeline's results with the ethograms up to frame 16650. Sorry for the confusion.

Messages.Author: Ben Nikolas Baute
Messages.Content: Hello, was somebody able to get deeplabcut running with GPU support? I was able to get cuda 12.5 running, but deeplabcut is unable to use it. As far as I understand, deeplabcut needs cuda 11.8 to run. The problem Is that it was not possible to get cuda 11.8 running, because always some dependencies or packages are broken. I removed my ubuntu several times and tried different ways to install it but it never worked. Currently the only way to use it is with CPU, which is too slow to get work down. Using Google Colab was also not very helpful as I only got to train once and afterwards I am not allowed to use the GPU anymore.  - Ben

Messages.Author: David Pierre Kehrer
Messages.Content: Hey, I use Linux subsystem for Windows Ubuntu 22.04 4 LTS, Jammy. Here I used the conda provided by deeplabcut and adapted it to the following versions: " import deeplabcut import tensorflow as tf import tensorrt as trt  print("TensorFlow version:", tf.__version__) print("CUDA version:", tf.sysconfig.get_build_info()["cuda_version"]) print("cuDNN version:", tf.sysconfig.get_build_info()["cudnn_version"]) print("Num GPUs Available: ", len(tf.config.list_physical_devices('GPU'))) print("tensorrt version:", trt.__version__) " You should get: TensorFlow version: 2.12.0 CUDA version: 11.8 cuDNN version: 8 Num GPUs Available: 1 tensorrt version: 10.0.1  I did have to tinker a little to get it to work in the end. But it's possible :D

Messages.Author: Marcus Nicolaas Boon
Messages.Content: This is the link for the DLC workshop data: bit.ly/4dlhssH
